data.title: Military Coup Ousts Government of São Tomé in West Africa
data.meta_description: Soldiers topple government of tiny West African nation of Sao Tome and Principe while Pres Fradique de Menezes is out of country; Menezes appeals to fellow African leaders for help in restoring him to power; Maj Fernando Pereira, leader of coup, declares state of emergency and says he wants to form transitional government; says people are dying of hunger and politicians do nothing; Sao Tome has what may be billions of barrels of crude lying off its coast, though no oil has yet been found; this has prompted political turmoil and wrangling; coup is being condemned by members of African Union and by United States; map (M)
data.text:
Soldiers toppled the government of the tiny and potentially oil-lush West African nation of São Tomé and Príncipe at dawn today while the president was out of the country.

Soldiers with machine guns patrolled the quiet streets of the capital after taking control of critical sites in a flurry of shooting around 3 a.m.

President Fradique de Menezes was in neighboring Nigeria, working to help São Tomé develop its potential oil producing capacity, when the soldiers seized power in a move they said was intended to end the country's abject poverty.

Mr. Menezes appealed to fellow African leaders for help in restoring him to power. The Nigerian government wasted no time in issuing a strong warning that fell just short of a threat of military intervention should its interests be jeopardized.

The leader of the coup, Maj. Fernando Pereira, declared a state of emergency and said he wanted to form a transitional government.

''The people are dying of hunger,'' Major Pereira told reporters. ''The politicians are doing nothing.'' He said soldiers were also suffering.

Soldiers detained Prime Minister Maria das Neves and senior officials including the public works minister, Joaquim Rafael Branco, who is responsible for the oil reserves that could determine the country's future.

Major Pereira declared a dusk-to-dawn curfew, and coup leaders were meeting with the detained officials.

São Tomé has been shaken by political turmoil, partly because of wrangling over what may be billions of barrels of crude lying off its coast, though no oil has yet been found.

Africa's west coast, with oil reserves stretching from Angola north to Nigeria, is taking on increasing strategic significance as the United States tries to reduce its reliance on Middle Eastern sources.

The United States condemned the overthrow and urged the release of the detained ministers. ''We deplore these actions,'' said Richard A. Boucher, the State Department spokesman.

In the Nigerian capital, Abuja, Mr. Menezes called for help from ''all democrats, world leaders and African leaders'' to end the coup.

''Africa cannot attain greatness with bad governance, corruption and coups d'état,'' he said. ''We must toe the path of democracy, good governance, transparency and civil liberty.''

The African Union called on the coup leaders to release the government members. Portugal, the country's former colonial master, called the coup ''an attempt to upset constitutional order.''

South Africa, Zimbabwe, Senegal and Ghana also condemned the coup. There was no immediate comment from Angola, which helped end a coup in São Tomé in 1995, when young officers took over the country for a week to protest poverty. They were pardoned after Angolan mediators persuaded them to return to their barracks.
